title: Alan Sugar says he's irreplaceable as he talks quitting The Apprentice
text:
Alan Sugar insists The Apprentice wouldn’t be the same without him (Picture: Getty Images)

The Apprentice is currently part way through its 15th series, and still going strong after being on our screens for more than a decade.

But despite keeping it fresh, it sounds as though Lord Alan Sugar himself is hoping to have some downtime in the next five years.

That’s right, the 72-year-old has opened up on how long he thinks he can keep up the business show, and hopes to retire on the 20th series.

After all, he would be 77 by then, this man needs a break.

When chatting to journalist Laura Harding (via The Herald) the entrepreneur revealed his plans for the future of the show.

He said: ‘I’ve often had thoughts of when am I going to give it up, Next season will be the 16th. I think I would max out at 20 years, a 20-year ceremony.

He believes he is irreplaceable (Picture: BBC)

‘I think enough is enough then, I would be 77 and I might not be compos mentis by then, you never know.’

But despite potentially leaving our screens, that doesn’t mean the show can’t go on without him – although it appears Alan believes he’s irreplaceable with the history he’s had.

‘I’ve done it all,’ the star protested when asked if there would be someone big enough to fill his shoes: ‘So I think they would find it very hard.’

The founder of the show continued: ‘If you look at some of the other business programmes that are on TV, I’m not sure there is such an all rounder there.’

Shahin Hassan was the first contestant to be fired in this series (Picture: BBC)

To give him his due, he has been grafting since he left the womb.

He boasted: ‘I’ve loaded lorries, sat on the production line, produced more goods on the production line than any of these people have ever done, done my own marketing, my own advertising, buying components, getting the prices right, designing products.’

You get the idea.

The 15th series launched last week and already saw chartered engineer Shahin Hassan fired from the boardroom.

‘I’m very disappointed to leave at such an early stage – it should have been Lewis, but ultimately it was Lord Sugar’s decision,’ he said in the taxi ride home.
